facts.text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated March 28, 1968 of the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in Income-tax Reference No. 11 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated March 28, 1968 of the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in Income-tax Reference No. 1 1 of 1963.

facts.text: The assessee is a firm carrying on mining business at Udaipur with a branch at Mandal.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, a firm carrying on mining business at Udaipur with a branch at Mandal, had pursuant to an invitation to tender for mica mining

facts.text: Assessee tendered for certain areas for Rs. 1,57,150/- of which Rs. 3,360/- was payable towards the mica scrap lying on the surface.

anchor.surface_text: had pursuant to an invitation to tender for mica mining in accordance with the terms and conditions prescribed in the Mineral Concession Rules, tendered for certain areas for Rs. 1,57,150/- of which Rs. 3,360/- was payable towards the mica scrap lying on the surface.

facts.text: The lease was for 20 years and the areas which were offered had been worked by other Private companies for 15 years.

anchor.surface_text: The lease was for 20 years and the areas which were offered had been worked by other Private companies for 15 years. This offer of the appellant was accepted and the lease was granted to it.

facts.text: Relevant assessment year 1952-53 for which the previous year for the head office ended on October 30, 1951 and for the branch ended on March 30, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: In the relevant assessment year 1952-53 for which the previous year for the head office ended on October 30, 1951 and for the branch ended on March 30, 1952, the appellant claimed Rs. 7,857/-

facts.text: Appellant claimed Rs. 7,857/- being the 1/20th of the tender money as revenue expenditure incurred during that year.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant claimed Rs. 7,857/- being the 1/20th of the tender money as revenue expenditure incurred during that year.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the claim on the ground that the money was paid for the value of the land which it had acquired because the mine had already been worked by private companies.

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the assessee was rejected by the Income-tax Officer on the ground that the money was paid for the value of the land which it had acquired because the mine granted to the assessee had already been worked by the private companies.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the disallowance as capital expenditure for acquisition of capital asset.

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal against this order, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the disallowance of the expenditure as in his view, it was a capital nature expended for the acquisition of a, capital asset.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed Rs. 3,360/- paid for mica scrap on surface as revenue expenditure but disallowed balance Rs. 1,53,800/- as capital expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal however allowed Rs. 3,360/paid for mica scrap lying on the surface as a revenue expenditure incurred in the acquisition of stock-in-trade, but disallowed the claim for the balance of Rs. 1,53,800/- which was paid under the tender as a capital expenditure.

facts.text: Assessee claimed Rs. 3,200 as fee paid at Re. 1/- per acre per year for prospecting licence.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee had also claimed Rs. 3,200 as the fee paid by it a the rate of Re. 1/- per acre per year for prospecting licence.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed Rs. 3,200 under s. 10(2)(xv) of the Act as initial expenditure for procuring right to prospect mines.

anchor.surface_text: The income-tax Officer disallowed this amount under s. 10 2   xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  hereinafter called the Act  on the ground that the licence was obtained by the assessee only that year, that the fee was paid in addition to the royalty payable on the value of the emeralds excavated and sold and that it was an initial expenditure for procuring a right to respect mines.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner negatived the claim for prospecting licence fee as assessee had right to win and commercially exploit minerals.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner in an appeal by the assessee negatived the claim on the ground that under that licence the assessee had a right to win and commercially exploit the minerals which the assessee actually carried out.

facts.text: Tribunal dismissed appeal on prospecting fee, holding it not for stock-in-trade, mine not yet started, payment to initiate business, period one year.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal while dismissing the appeal filed against the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner observed that the prospecting licence fee cannot be equated to a payment made for the purchase of stock-in-trade, that it was number based, on any quantity of minerals, that the minerals had to be won and extracted from the earth and the term prospecting licence shows that the mine had number yet started working as a mine and that the payment was to initiate the business.-It also held that the period of on,-- year for which the licence was obtained cannot justify the fee paid as a revenue expenditure.

facts.text: Assessee filed application under s. 66(1) and Tribunal referred two questions to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee thereafter filed application under s. 66 1  of the Act and as in its opinion a question of law did arise, the, Tribunal referred the following two questions to the High Court for its opinion -

facts.text: Questions referred: 1. Whether prospecting licence fee of Rs. 3,200/- allowable as revenue expenditure? 2. Whether part of Rs. 1,53,800/- allowable as revenue expenditure?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the prospecting licence fee of Rs. 3,200/is allowable as revenue expenditure ? Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the caste the appropriate Part of Rs. 1,53,800/- was allowable as revenue expenditure ?

facts.text: High Court answered both questions in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Rajasthan in I an income-tax reference under s., 66  1   by which it answered the two questions referred to it in the negative.

facts.text: Appeal No. 1238/1969 filed on certificate but dismissed without comments as High Court gave no reasons for certificate.

anchor.surface_text: Before this appeal was filed, Appeal No. 1238/1969 had been filed on a certificate but that is dismissed without companyts because this Court had in several cases held that in Income-tax references if the High Court does number give any reasons while granting the certificate, the certificate can be revoked.

facts.text: Areas worked by private companies for 15 years, value determined on principles of mine valuation.

anchor.surface_text: As the area has been worked by a private company- pany during the past fifteen years, all the known mines and quarries and prospecting pits have acquired a value which can be determined on the principles of mine valuation.

facts.text: Mica scrap on surface to be removed by predecessor or forfeited to government, not to come to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: when the lease was allotted to the appellant by the Mining Department it was made clear that any mica scrap left by the predecessor exploiters M s. Duduwala Co., on the surface would be removed either by these exploiters within three months or if number so removed it would stand forfeited to the Rajasthan Government in any case it was number to companye to the appellants.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Rs. 1,53,800/- as capital expenditure as right to extract mica from pillars embedded in land.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the ,expenditure incurred is a capital expenditure and that the second question has been rightly answered.

facts.text: Prospecting licence for one year at Re. 1 per acre per year.

anchor.surface_text: That apart, the period for which the licence was obtained viz., one year, does number also make it a revenue payment

facts.text: Supreme Court holds prospecting licence fee of Rs. 3,200/- as capital expenditure for initiating business.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the Income-tax authorities, the Tribunal and the High Court are right in companying to that companyclusion.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The two questions having been answered against the assessee, the appeal is dismissed with companyts.

holdings.text: where minerals have to be won, extracted and brought to surface by mining operations, the expenditure incurred for acquiring such a right would be of a capital nature. But where the mineral has already been gotten and is on the surface, then the expenditure incurred for obtaining the right to acquire the raw material-that is- the mineral, would be a revenue expenditure laid out for the acquisition of stock-in-trade.

anchor.surface_text: If we confine our attention to the mining leases, what appears to us to be an empirical test is that where minerals have to be won, extracted and brought to surface by mining operations, the expenditure incurred for acquiring such a right would be of a capital nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies enduring benefit test from Atherton and Pingle Industries; distinguishes surface mineral cases like Jabbar, Mohanlal, Golden Horse Shoe where no extraction needed; empirical test based on need for mining operations.

holdings.text: the principles which have been applied in the Pingle Industries case are equally applicable to the facts and circumstances of this case. The test for ascertaining whether the amount spent is of a capital nature is, whether it was spent for obtaining a right of an enduring character which in the case of mining leases is to acquire rights over land for winning the mineral.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the principles which have been applied in the Pingle Industries case are equally applicable to the facts and circumstances of this case. The test for ascertaining whether the amount spent is of a capital nature is, whether it was spent for obtaining a right of an enduring character which in the case of mining leases is to acquire rights over land for winning the mineral.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Pingle Industries directly; mica pillars embedded requiring extraction despite prior working; enhanced value but still capital for enduring right over land.

holdings.text: We accordingly hold that the expenditure incurred is a capital expenditure and that the second question has been rightly answered.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the ,expenditure incurred is a capital expenditure and that the second question has been rightly answered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court and lower authorities; applies mining expenditure test to facts where mica in pillars embedded in land.

holdings.text: the fee was paid for initiating the business and is of a capital nature. By no stretch of argument can the fee paid for a prospecting licence be equated to a payment made for the purposes of stock-in-trade.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore clear that the fee was paid for initiating the business and is of a capital nature. By no stretch of argument can the fee paid for a prospecting licence be equated to a payment made for the purposes of stock-in-trade.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms lower authorities and Tribunal findings of fact; fee irrespective of quantity, for prospecting/initiation despite win rights under rules; short period reinforces capital.

holdings.text: We think that the Income-tax authorities, the Tribunal and the High Court are right in coming to that conclusion. Our answer to the first question is, therefore also in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the Income-tax authorities, the Tribunal and the High Court are right in coming to that conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with factual findings that prospecting fee initiates business, not stock purchase; rejects equation to revenue despite commercial win rights.

precedents.citation: Pingle Industries Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad 1 ... 1 40 I.T.R. 67.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Pingle Industries Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad 1  had occasion to examine exhaustively the relevant Indian and English cases for determining what is a capital expenditure and what is a revenue expenditure. That was also a case of mining where the assessee obtained leases for excavating Shahabad stones for a period of 12 years for which an annual payment of Rs. 28,000 was agreed upon. The majority of Judges, Kapur, J. and Hidayatullah, J.

precedents.case_name: Pingle Industries Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad
precedents.cited_proposition: determining what is a capital expenditure and what is a revenue expenditure in mining leases; payment for long term lease to win stones is capital as stones in situ are capital asset not stock-in-trade
precedents.cited_holding: the assessee acquired by his long term lease the right to win stones, that the stones in situ were number its stock-in-trade in a business sense but a capital asset from which after extraction it companyverted the stones into its stock-in-trade. It was also held that the payment was neither rent number royalty but a lump payment in instalments for acquiring a capital asset of enduring benefit

Ltd. 2  that in the absence of any special circumstances leading to the opposite companyclusion, when an expenditure is made, number only once and for all, but with a view to bringing it into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of a trade, has been applied, explained and varied from time to time as the circumstances of the particular case required.

precedents.cited_proposition: expenditure made once and for all with a view to bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of a trade is capital

edges.explanation: Applies test to facts relevant to issue: 'the principles which have been applied in the Pingle Industries case are equally applicable to the facts and circumstances of this case. The test for ascertaining whether the amoun...'

anchor.surface_text: In our view the principles which have been applied in the Pingle Industries case are equally applicable to the facts and circumstances of this case. The test for ascertaining whether the amount spent is of a capital nature is, whether it was spent for obtaining a right of an enduring character which in the case of mining leases is to acquire rights over land for winning the mineral.
The two questions having been answered against the assessee, the appeal is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore clear that the fee was paid for initiating the business and is of a capital nature. By no stretch of argument can the fee paid for a prospecting licence be equated to a payment made for the purposes of stock-in-trade.

edges.explanation: The issue concerns whether the prospecting licence fee is allowable as revenue expenditure, directly addressing Section 10(2)(xv) which pertains to allowable deductions
The issue questions the allowability of the prospecting licence fee as revenue expenditure, directly addressing the concept that such fees are capital as initiation of business.
